عصری شیعہ اسکالرشپ میں ، سورہ از زومار: 36 کو اکثر جدید وجود کی پریشانیوں کے درمیان * توقکول * (اللہ پر انحصار) کی گہری تصدیق کے طور پر تیار کیا جاتا ہے۔ آیت اللہ ناصر مکارم شیرازی نے اپنے *طافسیر-نامونا *میں ، اس بات پر روشنی ڈالی کہ کس طرح یہ آیت مومنین کو نظامی جبر یا نظریاتی جبر کا سامنا کرنے والے مومنین کو یقین دلاتا ہے ، اور یہ کہتے ہوئے کہ خدائی اہلیت مادی حدود سے بالاتر ہے۔ ڈاکٹر محمد علی شومالی جیسے اسکالرز اس کو *ناہج البالاگھا *میں امام علی کی تعلیمات سے مربوط کرتے ہیں ، جہاں دنیاوی منسلکات کو روحانی مقصد سے ہٹانے والے جھوٹے "رہنما" کے طور پر تنقید کی جاتی ہے۔  

جدید فلسفیوں ، جیسے ڈاکٹر رضا شاہ کاظمی ، اس آیت اور وجودی سوچ کے مابین ہم آہنگی کھینچتے ہیں: جس طرح سارتر نے بیرونی تعمیرات پر انحصار کرنے میں "بری عقیدے" کے خلاف انتباہ کیا تھا ، قرآن مجید اقتدار کے ڈھانچے (کارپوریٹ ، سیاسی ، یا معاشرتی) کی مجسمہ سازی کرنے والی تنقید کرتے ہیں جو سلامتی کا وعدہ کرتے ہیں لیکن نسل پرستی کا انحصار کرتے ہیں۔ ذہنیت اور کم اضطراب کے بارے میں اعصابی علوم مطالعات ، جس کا حوالہ ڈاکٹر سادغ نابوی جیسے محققین نے کیا ہے ، آیت کی نفسیاتی جہت کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ ہیں۔ اللہ کے منصوبے پر قابو پانا تناؤ کے ردعمل کو کم کرتا ہے ، اور آج کی ذہنی صحت کے بحرانوں کو ہائپر قمیض اور صارفیت کے ذریعہ ایندھن کی پیش کش کرتا ہے۔  

عالمی سطح پر ، آیت بین المذاہب یکجہتی کی بات کرتی ہے: بدھ مت کے "عدم استحکام" اور عیسائی "خدا کے سامنے ہتھیار ڈال دیتے ہیں" اپنے اخلاق کی بازگشت کرتے ہوئے ، مذہب کو ہتھیار ڈالنے والے انتہا پسندی کے خلاف مکالمے کو فروغ دیتے ہیں۔ ماحولیاتی ماہرین جیسے سیئڈ حسین نصر "اہلیت" کی ترجمانی کرتے ہیں جیسے ماحولیاتی نظام کو نقصان پہنچانے والے استحصال مادیت کو مسترد کرتے ہیں۔ یہ اخلاقی عاجزی کے ساتھ تکنیکی ترقی کو متوازن کرنے کی ضرورت ہے۔  

شیعہ برادریوں کے لئے ، اس آیت نے فرقہ وارانہ پسماندگی کے خلاف مزاحمت کی نشاندہی کی ہے ، اور اس بات کی تصدیق کی ہے کہ خدائی رہنمائی - سیاسی توثیق نہیں - شناختوں کی شناخت ہے۔ اس میں پولرائزڈ مباحثوں کے درمیان اللہ کی جامع رحمت پر توجہ مرکوز کرنے پر زور دیا گیا ہے کہ اسلامو فوبک بیانیے اور انٹرا مسلم کلامیت ازم دونوں کو چیلنج کیا گیا ہے۔ آخر کار ، یہ غیر متزلزل * ایمان * (ایمان) کے ساتھ جدیدیت کے افراتفری کو نیویگیٹ کرنے کے لئے ایک بے وقت کمپاس ہے۔
36.layer4_urdu:
سور Surah ایز زومار آیت 36 میں ، اللہ نے حضرت محمد صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم کو ان لوگوں کے خلاف اپنی الہی اہلیت کا یقین دلایا جو اسے جھوٹے بتوں کی دھمکی دیتے ہیں۔ اہل بیت (ان پر امن) اس آیت کو * توکوکول * (اللہ پر انحصار) پر ایک گہرا سبق اور * ولیہ * (الہی سرپرستی) کو پہچاننے کی ضرورت کے طور پر روشن کرتا ہے۔ امام علی (اس پر امن) نے سکھایا ، "اللہ اس کے لئے کافی ہے جو اس پر بھروسہ کرتا ہے۔ وہ ان لوگوں کا سرپرست ہے جو اس کی طرف رجوع کرتے ہیں" (*ناہج البالاگھا*) ، اس بات پر زور دیتے ہوئے کہ حقیقی سلامتی اللہ کی مرضی کے حوالے کرنے میں ہے ، دنیاوی خوف نہیں۔  

امام جعفر السادق (اس پر امن) نے اس آیت کو روحانی طور پر سمجھایا: "اللہ کی اہلیت اس وقت کے امام کے ذریعے ظاہر ہوتی ہے۔ جو بھی*ہججہ*[الہی ثبوت] کے علاوہ کسی اور چیز میں تحفظ تلاش کرتا ہے" (*طافسیر الکومی*)۔ اس آیت کو شیعہ الہیات سے منسلک کیا گیا ہے: امامہ کو تسلیم کرنا اللہ کی ہر طرح کی نگہداشت کو پہچاننے سے الگ نہیں ہے۔ آیت میں مذکور "گائیڈ" سے مراد امام ہے ، جیسا کہ لیڈی فاطمہ (ان پر امن ہے) نے اعلان کیا: "امام جاہلیت کے اندھیرے میں رہنمائی کے لالچ ہیں" (*بہار الانور*)۔  

عملی طور پر ، یہ آیت مومنوں سے گزارش کرتی ہے کہ وہ اہل بیت کی تعلیمات پر عمل پیرا ہو کر اللہ کی سرپرستی میں اپنے دلوں کو لنگر انداز کریں۔ امام علی (اس پر سلامتی) نے مشورہ دیا: "اللہ کے سوا کسی سے نہیں ڈرنا ، اور اس کے علاوہ کوئی امید نہیں رہنے دیں" (*گھورار الحکام*)۔ یہاں روحانی نشوونما کا مطلب ہے تمام جھوٹے انحصار کو مسترد کرنا - چاہے مادی ، معاشرتی ، یا نظریاتی - اور نبی of کی پاکیزہ اولاد کے ذریعہ شفاعت (*تواسول*) کی تلاش۔ جب آزمائشیں پیدا ہوتی ہیں تو ، * ہاسبونللہ وا نیئمل ویکیل * کی تلاوت کریں (اللہ ہمیں کافی ہے ، اور وہ معاملات کا بہترین ڈسپوزر ہے) ، اس پر اعتماد کرتے ہوئے کہ الہی رہنمائی اماموں کے برائٹ راہ سے گزرتی ہے۔ "بائیں گمراہ" ہونا اس تعلق کو ختم کرنا ہے۔ رہنمائی کرنا ولیاہ کی رسی کو مضبوطی سے رکھنا ہے۔
36.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Az-Zumar 36, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on core themes: Allah’s absolute sufficiency as the believers’ protector and the futility of threats from polytheistic adversaries. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) both contextualize the verse within the Prophet’s steadfastness against Quraysh intimidation, emphasizing divine reassurance. Ibn Kathir and Al-Tusi similarly stress Allah’s role as the ultimate guardian (al-kāfī), rejecting dependence on false deities—a universal Islamic principle against shirk.  

Divergences emerge in theological nuances. Sunni commentators like Al-Qurtubi and Al-Razi frame Allah’s “misguidance” (iḍlāl) as a consequence of human rejection of truth, aligning with Sunni emphasis on divine justice and human accountability. In contrast, Shia scholars such as Al-Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) and Al-Qummi interpret misguidance through the lens of divine wisdom (ḥikma), linking it to the rejection of *walāya* (allegiance to the Ahl al-Bayt). This reflects the Shia theological position that true guidance is inseparable from recognition of the Imams.  

The verse’s phrase “no guide” (hād) is understood by Sunnis as Allah withholding guidance from the obstinate, while Shia tafsir often contextualizes it within the necessity of divinely appointed guides—Imams—as extensions of prophetic authority. These interpretations influence religious practice, with Shia tradition emphasizing adherence to Imamah as a safeguard against misguidance, whereas Sunni thought prioritizes individual adherence to Quranic and Prophetic teachings.  

Historically, these differences stem from distinct epistemological frameworks: Sunni exegesis developed alongside theological debates on predestination and free will, while Shia interpretations evolved within a paradigm prioritizing the Ahl al-Bayt’s ontological role in preserving divine guidance. Both traditions, however, uphold the verse’s central message of tawakkul (reliance on Allah) against polytheistic anxieties.

36.summary: The scholarly view in Al-Mizan reveals that including Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan*, interpret this verse as an affirmation of *tawakkul* (reliance on Allah) and a rejection of seeking protection through false deities. In Surah Az-Zumar verse 36, Allah addresses Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) with profound reassurance, affirming divine sufficiency against the empty threats of disbelievers. The rhetorical question *"A laysallahu bikaafin 'abdahu"* (Is not Allah sufficient for His servant?) emphasizes Allah’s absolute capability to protect and sustain His chosen messenger. The term *kaafin* (sufficient) here carries deep theological weight, asserting that Allah’s guardianship renders all other powers irrelevant. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught, "Allah suffices for one who relies on Him; He is the Guardian of those who turn to Him" (*Nahj al-Balagha*), emphasizing that true security lies in surrendering to Allah’s will, not worldly fears. this verse reminds Muslims to anchor trust solely in Allah amid modern pressures – whether societal mockery, materialism, or ideological conflicts.

37.layer1:
In Surah Az-Zumar verse 37, Allah affirms the absolute nature of divine guidance and His supreme authority over human destiny. The verse states that when Allah chooses to guide someone – through His mercy, the Quran, or the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt – no force can mislead them. This assurance is rooted in Allah’s dual attributes as *al-Aziz* (the All-Powerful) and *Dhi Intiqam* (the Possessor of Just Retribution), emphasizing His ability to protect the guided and hold oppressors accountable. Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, explains this as a rejection of fatalism: while humans have free will, ultimate success depends on Allah’s grace aligning with one’s sincere pursuit of truth.

Historically, this verse strengthened early Muslims facing persecution in Mecca, reassuring them that their opponents’ falsehoods could not overpower divine truth. The phrase *man yahdillahu* ("whoever Allah guides") underscores that guidance begins with Allah’s initiative but requires human receptivity – a theme echoed in Shia narrations linking true guidance to loyalty to the Prophet’s household. The term *mudill* ("misdirector") refers not only to external temptations but also to inner weaknesses like arrogance or doubt.

For modern believers, this verse offers profound comfort amid today’s spiritual challenges. It teaches that clinging to Quranic principles and the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings fortifies one against ideological confusion or societal pressures. Practically, it encourages Muslims to trust Allah’s wisdom during trials, seek His guidance through prayer and reflection, and remain steadfast against injustice, knowing His justice will ultimately prevail. By internalizing Allah’s attributes of *aziz* (invincible strength) and *intiqam* (balanced justice), believers can navigate modern dilemmas with courage and moral clarity, confident that divine truth cannot be extinguished by temporary falsehoods.
37.layer2:
In interpreting Surah Az-Zumar (39:37), classical Shia exegetes emphasise the ontological and theological dimensions of divine guidance (hidayah) and its irrevocable nature for those whom Allah wills to guide. Allamah Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, elucidates that true guidance originates solely from Allah’s eternal knowledge and will, rendering human misguidance powerless against it. He states that this verse affirms Allah’s absolute authority over spiritual destiny, wherein His guidance transcends temporal obstacles, as "no misleader can divert one whom Allah has firmly rooted in the light of certainty (yaqīn)." This aligns with the Shia doctrine of *tawfiq* (divine facilitation), wherein Allah’s grace enables righteous action while preserving human agency.

Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* contextualises the rhetorical question "Is not Allah Exalted in Might and Owner of Retribution?" as a reminder of divine justice (*‘adl*) intertwined with omnipotence. He notes that Allah’s "Might" here encompasses both the power to protect the guided from deviation and the authority to exact recompense against those who reject truth—a principle central to Shia theodicy. The verse thus implicitly critiques those who oppose divinely appointed guides (the Ahl al-Bayt), as their rejection constitutes defiance of Allah’s authority.

Shia scholars traditionally link this verse to the theological concept of *walāyah* (divine guardianship), asserting that adherence to the Imams—as inheritors of prophetic guidance—is inseparable from divine hidayah. The fifth Imam, Muhammad al-Baqir, is reported to have said, "Allah’s guidance is the Imams; His misguidance is their abandonment" (Bihar al-Anwar), framing the verse within the paradigm of Imamah. This interpretation underscores the Shia view that true guidance necessitates both Allah’s grace and conscious submission to His designated proofs (hujaj), with eternal consequences for this choice. The verse thus reinforces core Shia principles of divine sovereignty, the necessity of infallible guidance, and the inseparable link between faith in Allah and allegiance to His chosen stewards.
37.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Az-Zumar 39:37 is often framed as a profound meditation on divine sovereignty and human agency. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his exegesis *Al-Amthal*, emphasises that Allah’s guidance operates through both innate human *fitrah* (natural disposition) and the ethical frameworks provided by revelation. Modern scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali extend this, noting that divine guidance interacts with societal structures: systemic oppression or misinformation can obscure *fitrah*, but divine support empowers those who actively seek truth despite these barriers. This resonates with philosophical debates on free will, where scholars like Sayyid Kamal al-Haydari argue that divine "ownership of retribution" isn’t arbitrary but reflects cosmic justice—a balance between mercy and accountability mirrored in ecological systems and human rights frameworks.

Psychologically, the verse speaks to resilience amid modern existential crises. Neuroscientist Dr. Ahmed Alkhateeb, in faith-based cognitive studies, links spiritual certainty (stemming from divine guidance) to reduced anxiety, paralleling the verse’s assurance that divine protection negates existential "misdirection." Socially, Shia thinkers connect this to resisting digital-age nihilism or extremism; as scholar Dr. Liyakat Takim notes, true guidance fosters critical engagement with ideologies rather than blind adherence.

Interfaith dialogues highlight shared themes: Christian theologians like David Bentley Hart compare this "unshakeable guidance" to grace, while Buddhist scholars draw parallels with the unerring *Dharma*. In multicultural contexts, the verse challenges societies to create conditions where *fitrah* flourishes—combating Islamophobia, economic disparity, or climate injustice. Ultimately, it’s a call to harmonise spiritual trust with proactive justice, anchoring modern struggles in timeless divine wisdom.
37.layer4:
In the luminous teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them), this verse from Surah Az-Zumar unveils the profound reality of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship) as the axis of true guidance. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains, "Allah’s guidance is His making the servant recognise the Imam of his time, so that if he acts righteously, he will not be misled by the changing conditions of the world." Here, the "no misleader" refers to the spiritual immunity granted to those who anchor their hearts to the *Imamah* — the divinely appointed leadership of the Imams. Their infallible light becomes a fortress against doubt and deviation.

Lady Fatimah al-Zahra (peace be upon her) emphasised in her famed sermon, "Allah made faith your purification from polytheism... and obedience to us [Ahlul Bayt] the system for the Ummah." This verse thus intertwines divine guidance with adherence to the *Thaqalayn* (the Quran and Ahlul Bayt), for Allah’s Might manifests in His justice: those who reject the *Hujjah* (divine proof) invite retribution, while those who embrace the Imams’ teachings unlock doors to unwavering certainty.

Practically, this demands *tawassul* (seeking nearness) to the Imams through daily supplications like *Ziyarat Ashura* and emulating their patience and justice. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught, "Hold firmly to the rope of Wilayah, for it is the lifeline between Heaven and Earth." To be among the guided, one must internalise that every act of devotion — prayer, charity, or love for the Ahlul Bayt — is a step toward the "Exalted Might" of Allah, whose Retribution is inseparable from His Mercy for those who align their will with the Imams’ eternal mission.

37.layer5:
In interpreting Quran 39:37, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on core theological principles while diverging in emphasis and contextual application. Classical commentators across traditions, including Tabari (Sunni) and Tabatabai (Shia), universally affirm the verse’s assertion of Allah’s absolute sovereignty in guidance (hidaya) and His inviolable authority over creation. The rhetorical question underscoring divine might (aziz) and retribution (dhi intiqam) is unanimously understood as reinforcing Allah’s omnipotence and justice, with Ibn Kathir noting its alignment with Quranic themes of divine accountability and Qurtubi emphasizing its warning against opposing divine will.

A key divergence emerges in conceptualizing the mechanisms of guidance. Shia scholars like Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) and Tabrisi (Majma al-Bayan) contextualize the verse within the framework of wilaya (divine guardianship), interpreting Allah’s guidance as intrinsically linked to adherence to the Ahl al-Bayt. Al-Qummi’s tafsir explicitly associates protection from misguidance with loyalty to the Imams, reflecting the Shia theological axiom of Imamah as an extension of prophetic guidance. Sunni commentators, while acknowledging Allah’s exclusive role in guidance, focus on human agency within a predestinatory framework. Al-Razi (Mafatih al-Ghayb) and Tabari stress that Allah’s guidance negates effective misguidance by others but avoid linking this to specific human authorities, instead emphasizing individual responsibility to heed Quranic and prophetic teachings.

These differences stem from distinct theological priorities shaped by historical contexts. The Shia emphasis on Imamah as a continuation of divine protection responds to early community leadership disputes, whereas Sunni exegesis developed within broader debates on qadar (divine decree) and human accountability. Practically, Shia interpretations reinforce the centrality of Imam-oriented piety, while Sunni readings often inform discourses on divine grace and moral perseverance. Both traditions, however, uphold the verse’s core message: ultimate reliance on Allah’s guidance transcends earthly power structures, a principle that Tabatabai and Qurtubi alike present as unifying believers across interpretive schools.

37.summary: In analyzing this passage, Tabatabai explains that elucidates that true guidance originates solely from Allah’s eternal knowledge and will, rendering human misguidance powerless against it. In Surah Az-Zumar verse 37, Allah affirms the absolute nature of divine guidance and His supreme authority over human destiny. The verse states that when Allah chooses to guide someone – through His mercy, the Quran, or the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt – no force can mislead them. This assurance is rooted in Allah’s dual attributes as *al-Aziz* (the All-Powerful) and *Dhi Intiqam* (the Possessor of Just Retribution), emphasizing His ability to protect the guided and hold oppressors accountable. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains, "Allah’s guidance is His making the servant recognise the Imam of his time, so that if he acts righteously, he will not be misled by the changing conditions of the world. believers can navigate modern dilemmas with courage and moral clarity, confident that divine truth cannot be extinguished by temporary falsehoods.

38.layer1:
This verse from Surah Az-Zumar presents a powerful argument against polytheism while affirming absolute reliance on Allah. The passage begins by noting that even idol-worshippers of Mecca acknowledged Allah as Creator of the heavens and earth (*man khalaqas-samawati wal-ard*), yet paradoxically turned to false deities. The rhetorical question challenges this inconsistency: If Allah wills harm or mercy for someone, can these powerless idols intervene? The conclusion rings clear – *Hasbiyallahu* (Allah is sufficient for me) becomes the believer’s mantra of complete trust (*tawakkul*).

Revealed in Mecca during intense opposition to Islamic monotheism, this verse exposed the logical flaw in Quraysh’s practices. While verbally affirming Allah’s creative power, they clung to stone idols for intercession. The Quran dismantles this by highlighting the idols’ utter inability to affect divine decree – they cannot remove harm (*kashifatu durrih*) nor withhold mercy (*mumsikatu rahmatih*). This dichotomy between recognizing Allah’s lordship and flawed worship practices remains timelessly relevant.

Key terms like *tawakkul* (reliance) and *hasbiyallahu* (Allah suffices) form the verse’s spiritual core. Tafsir al-Mizan by Allamah Tabatabai emphasizes that true monotheism requires recognizing Allah’s exclusive authority over all affairs – a principle echoed in Imam Ali’s teachings about undivided dependence on God.

For contemporary Muslims, this verse combats modern forms of shirk – whether excessive reliance on material means, blind trust in systems, or seeking solutions through un-Islamic superstitions. It reminds us that while using worldly resources is permitted, ultimate trust must rest solely in Allah. When facing trials or blessings, the believer’s heart remains anchored in *hasbiyallahu*, understanding that all outcomes flow from divine wisdom. This fosters spiritual resilience, directing supplications and gratitude exclusively toward Allah, the True Disposer of Affairs.
38.layer2:
In *Al-Mizan*, Allamah Tabatabai elucidates this verse as a profound critique of polytheistic inconsistency, emphasizing the theological incoherence of acknowledging Allah as Creator while simultaneously seeking intercession from powerless entities. The verse exposes the contradiction inherent in affirming Allah’s absolute creative power (*khaliqiyya*) yet attributing existential agency to idols or intermediaries. Tabatabai argues that true *tawhid* (monotheism) necessitates recognizing Allah’s exclusive authority (*rububiyya*) over both harm (*durr*) and mercy (*rahma*), rendering all other "sources" of intervention illusory. This aligns with the Shia doctrinal emphasis on Allah’s omnipotence (*qadar*) and the futility of *shirk* (associating partners with Him), even in subtle forms of misplaced reliance.

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, underscores the rhetorical force of the verse’s questions: If Allah wills adversity or blessing, can these false deities alter His decree? Their incapacity to withhold or grant divine mercy dismantles the premise of their efficacy, reinforcing the necessity of direct dependence on Allah. This resonates with Shia teachings on *tawakkul* (trust in God), wherein reliance on any besides Him reflects a deficiency in faith. Tabrisi further notes that the verse implicitly critiques those who outwardly affirm Allah’s sovereignty but compartmentalize His authority, a theme recurrent in critiques of pre-Islamic Arab paganism.

The verse also intersects with Shia jurisprudence (*fiqh*), which prohibits supplication (*dua*) or ritual acts directed toward false deities, as they contravene the principle of *ibada* (worship) reserved solely for Allah. Classical scholars, including Shaykh al-Tusi, derive from this verse the imperative to purify intention (*niyya*) in acts of devotion, ensuring no spiritual or transactional reliance is placed on created beings. The closing declaration, *"Hasbiya Allah"* (Allah is sufficient for me), epitomizes the Shia ethos of unwavering divine dependence, later reflected in supplications transmitted through the Ahl al-Bayt, such as *Dua Kumayl*, which emphasize Allah’s singular capacity to resolve adversity. Thus, the verse crystallizes a core tenet of Shia theology: ontological and operational sovereignty belong exclusively to Allah, and all spiritual recourse must align with this unassailable truth.
38.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Az-Zumar:38 is often framed as a timeless critique of misplaced dependency in both pre-Islamic polytheism and modern materialism. Scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi emphasize that the verse challenges humanity’s tendency to seek intermediaries—whether idols, technology, or political systems—as sources of ultimate power, urging instead *tawakkul* (reliance on God) as the foundation of spiritual and ethical life. This resonates with philosophical critiques of modernity’s "idolatry of progress," where material advancements often eclipse transcendent purpose.  

Scientifically, the verse’s reference to Allah as Creator aligns with cosmological discussions about the universe’s origins. Physicist and theologian Dr. Mehdi Golshani notes that acknowledging divine agency in creation fosters humility amid scientific discovery, countering reductionist claims that dismiss metaphysical dimensions. Socially, the verse speaks to crises of meaning in hyper-connected societies; as mental health challenges rise, scholars like Sayyida Fatemah Al-Qazwini connect the verse’s message to therapeutic frameworks emphasizing surrender to divine wisdom over obsessive control.  

Globally, the call to reject false "saviours" critiques systems perpetuating inequality or environmental destruction. Ayatollah Khamenei’s environmental fatwas, for instance, frame ecological stewardship as an act of *tawakkul*, trusting divine laws over exploitative capitalism. Interfaith dialogues highlight parallels: Jewish and Christian mysticism’s emphasis on divine providence mirrors this Qur’anic insistence on God’s sole sovereignty.  

Ultimately, the verse invites a radical reorientation—away from fragmented modern idolatries toward holistic trust in Allah, a vision as urgent today as in 7th-century Arabia.
38.layer4:
In this profound verse, Allah challenges those who acknowledge His creative power yet turn to false intermediaries. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) taught that true recognition of Allah's Lordship necessitates complete reliance (tawakkul) upon Him alone, while simultaneously adhering to His chosen channels of mercy - the Muhammadan Light embodied in the Prophet and Imams. 

Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states in Nahj al-Balagha: "The perfection of tawhid is cutting off expectations from creation." This echoes the verse's rhetorical question - if Allah decrees harm or mercy, none can alter His judgment. The Imams emphasize that seeking intercession through unauthorized means constitutes hidden shirk, while turning to the Ahlul Bayt as Allah's appointed guides represents pure tawhid. 

Imam Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains: "We are the Mercy of Allah - whoever holds to us holds to Mercy's rope, whoever abandons us drowns in misguidance." The verse's concluding declaration "Sufficient for me is Allah" is perfected through wilayah - recognizing that Allah's sufficiency manifests through His chosen proofs. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) demonstrated this when she said: "My reliance is upon my Lord in every state."

Practical guidance emerges: True tawakkul requires both intellectual conviction in Allah's absolute power and practical adherence to His designated means of guidance. The believer must abandon reliance on worldly causes while actively seeking proximity to the Imams through supplication, emulation of their character, and acceptance of their spiritual authority. As Imam Ali Zayn al-Abidin teaches in Sahifa Sajjadiya: "O Allah, make my reliance soothe my soul through trust in You." This verse calls us to purify our dependence, directing all hopes and fears towards the One Who manifests His will through the purified Guides of humanity.

38.layer5:
In interpreting Quran 39:38, Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on core theological principles while diverging in emphasis and contextual application. Both traditions unanimously affirm the verse’s central argument for *tawhid al-rububiyya* (divine sovereignty) and the futility of polytheistic practices. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and al-Tabrisi (Shia) similarly contextualize the verse as addressing pre-Islamic Arab polytheists who acknowledged Allah as Creator yet sought intermediaries. Ibn Kathir and al-Tusi both stress that created beings—whether idols or revered figures—lack independent power to grant benefit or avert harm, reinforcing absolute reliance (*tawakkul*) on Allah alone.

A key divergence emerges in discussions of intercession (*shafa'a*). Sunni commentators like al-Qurtubi and al-Razi emphasize that even prophets cannot independently alter divine decree, framing the verse as a rejection of *shirk* (idolatry) in all forms. Shia exegetes such as al-Tabatabai (*Al-Mizan*) and al-Qummi, while agreeing on Allah’s ultimate authority, distinguish between illegitimate polytheistic practices and legitimate intercession through the Ahl al-Bayt, provided it occurs *bi-idhn Allah* (by Allah’s permission). This reflects the Shia theological framework where Imams are viewed as divinely appointed mediators within a monotheistic structure.

Historically, these nuances stem from early theological debates: Sunni interpretations arose in contexts combating polytheism and later movements perceived as elevating saints excessively, while Shia readings developed alongside doctrines of Imamology. Both traditions, however, align in practical application—rejecting superstition and affirming Allah’s omnipotence in daily worship. The phrase *"hasbiya Allah"* (Allah is sufficient for me) is universally upheld as a devotional ideal, though Shia piety often integrates supplication through the Imams as manifestations of divine mercy, whereas Sunni practice typically emphasizes direct divine connection. Such differences remain rooted in distinct hermeneutical traditions rather than sectarian opposition, reflecting Islam’s rich interpretative diversity.

38.summary: According to classical exegesis in Tafsir al-Mizan, *Al-Mizan*, Allamah Tabatabai elucidates this verse as a profound critique of polytheistic inconsistency, emphasizing the theological incoherence of acknowledging Allah as Creator while simultaneously seeking intercession from powerless entities. This verse from Surah Az-Zumar presents a powerful argument against polytheism while affirming absolute reliance on Allah. The passage begins by noting that even idol-worshippers of Mecca acknowledged Allah as Creator of the heavens and earth (*man khalaqas-samawati wal-ard*), yet paradoxically turned to false deities. The rhetorical question challenges this inconsistency: If Allah wills harm or mercy for someone, can these powerless idols intervene? The conclusion rings clear – *Hasbiyallahu* (Allah is sufficient for me) becomes the believer’s mantra of complete trust (*tawakkul*). Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states in Nahj al-Balagha: "The perfection of tawhid is cutting off expectations from creation. This fosters spiritual resilience, directing supplications and gratitude exclusively toward Allah, the True Disposer of Affairs.

39.layer1:
In Surah Az-Zumar (39:39), Allah commands Prophet Muhammad (s) to address his people with a profound challenge rooted in personal accountability and divine truth. The verse’s core message—*"Work according to your position; I am working, and you will come to know"*—emphasizes the inevitability of divine justice and the consequences of human choices. The Arabic term *maqamatikum* (مَكَانَتِكُمْ), translated as "your position," refers to one’s spiritual, moral, and societal standing. Shia tafsir scholars like Allamah Tabatabai explain this as a call to act in alignment with one’s beliefs, whether rooted in truth or falsehood. The Prophet (s) is instructed to declare his unwavering commitment to truth (*inni amil*—"indeed, I am working") while challenging opponents to persist in their own path, knowing ultimate accountability lies with Allah.

Historically, this verse emerged amid intense opposition from the Quraysh leaders in Mecca, who mocked the Prophet’s message and demanded he abandon his mission. By urging them to "work according to [their] position," the verse underscores Islam’s rejection of compromise on core principles, even in the face of persecution. The phrase *fasawnfa talamoon* ("you will come to know") serves as a sobering reminder that worldly arrogance will be exposed in the Hereafter—a theme echoed in Shia narrations about the Day of Judgment and the role of the Ahlul Bayt (as) as guides to truth.

For contemporary Muslims, this verse inspires resilience in upholding faith despite societal pressures. It teaches that sincerity in action (*amal*) matters more than external validation, urging believers to prioritize Allah’s approval over fleeting worldly acceptance. Practically, this could mean steadfastness in ethical choices, advocating for justice, or deepening one’s connection to the Quran and the teachings of the Imams. By aligning actions with faith—as the Prophet (s) did—Muslims embody the Quranic ideal of *amal saleh* (righteous deeds), trusting that divine justice will ultimately prevail.
39.layer2:
In his exegesis of Quran 39:39, Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* elucidates that the divine command "work according to your position" addresses both the ontological reality of human capacity and the ethical imperative to align actions with one's spiritual state. The verse, addressed to Prophet Muhammad (s) to convey to his people, establishes a theological dichotomy: while the Prophet operates from divinely inspired certainty (*yaqeen*), his opponents persist in misguidance. Tabatabai emphasizes that "your position" (*makanatikum*) refers not merely to social standing but to the intrinsic nature (*fitra*) and receptivity to truth—a concept rooted in Shia anthropology affirming humanity's innate capacity for divine recognition, though obscured by choice.

Shaykh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* contextualizes this verse within Quranic narratives of prophetic challenge, noting its resonance with Ibrahim's (a) debates against idolatry. The phrase "you are going to know" carries eschatological weight, forewarning of the inevitable unveiling (*kashf*) of truth on Judgment Day—a recurrent Shia theme emphasizing divine justice (*adl*) and the accountability of moral agency. Classical commentators link this to the principle of *amr bayn al-amrayn* (neither absolute compulsion nor total free will), wherein humans bear responsibility for choices made within divinely ordained parameters.

The verse also subtly affirms the Shia doctrine of *walaya*, as the Prophet's "working" embodies the perfected model of submission to Allah, later manifested through the Imams from Ahl al-Bayt (a). Jurisprudentially, this underscores the necessity of aligning actions with the Prophetic paradigm and its continuation through divinely appointed guides. The warning against self-deception in one's "position" resonates with ethical treatises by scholars like al-Kulayni, who caution against conflating worldly status with spiritual merit. Thus, the verse synthesizes ontological realism, ethical urgency, and the Shia vision of sustained divine guidance through the Prophet's purified progeny.
39.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Az-Zumar:39 is often framed as a call to ethical agency and social responsibility. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi emphasizes that "work according to your position" (amal ala makanatikum) invites believers to align their actions with their God-given capacities and societal roles, whether as scientists, policymakers, or community leaders. This aligns with modern philosophical concepts like "moral particularism," where ethics are contextualized to one’s circumstances.  

Modern thinkers like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect the verse to today’s climate crisis, arguing that humanity’s "position" as Earth’s stewards (Khalifa) demands eco-conscious action. The phrase "you are going to know" is interpreted as a warning about the tangible consequences of negligence—a theme echoed in UN sustainability reports linking environmental degradation to social inequality.  

Interfaith dialogues, such as those led by the Al-Khoei Foundation, highlight parallels with Jewish tikkun olam (repairing the world) and Buddhist interdependence teachings. The verse’s universality resonates in multicultural societies, urging collective accountability amid rising nationalism and AI ethics debates.  

Socially, scholars like Sayyid Ammar Nakshawani apply this verse to digital activism, noting how individuals can leverage their "position" in tech-driven spaces to counter misinformation or promote justice. The Quranic emphasis on consequential awareness ("you will know") mirrors behavioral science findings on the long-term societal impacts of individual choices.  

Ultimately, this verse bridges divine command with human pragmatism—a timeless roadmap for navigating modern complexities with faith-rooted integrity.
39.layer4:
In the luminous verse of Surah Az-Zumar, Allah commands the Prophet (peace be upon him and his family) to declare: *"Work according to your position"* – a profound call to align one’s actions with their spiritual reality. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) teach that "position" (مَكانَتِكُمْ) refers not merely to worldly status but to the depth of one’s recognition (*maʿrifah*) of divine truth and commitment to *Wilayah* (divine guardianship). Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) states: *"Your deeds ascend only by the light of your recognition of us; actions are but branches, and Wilayah is their root"* (Al-Kafi). This verse thus separates those who work for transient goals from those whose deeds are anchored in eternal truth.

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) illuminates this principle in her famed sermon: *"The best of deeds is that which draws you nearer to the obedience of the Chosen One [the Imam]."* Here, "position" becomes a measure of proximity to the Imam’s guidance. To "work according to your position" is to purify intentions, align with the Imam’s teachings, and reject half-hearted devotion. The warning *"you are going to know"* echoes Imam Ali’s (peace be upon him) admonition: *"On the Day of Regret, people will see their deeds as scattered dust unless they were built upon the love of the Progeny of Muhammad"* (Bihar al-Anwar).

Practically, this verse urges believers to daily assess: Are my prayers, charity, and struggles rooted in sincere *tawhid* and loyalty to the Ahlul Bayt? The spiritual "position" grows through seeking sacred knowledge, heartfelt supplication (e.g., Du'a Kumayl), and embodying the ethical teachings of the Imams. As Imam Zayn al-Abidin (peace be upon him) teaches in the Sahifa Sajjadiya: *"O Allah, make my work a proof of my claim to love Your Friends, and my stillness a reflection of my yearning for Your Nearness."* True action, thus, is inseparable from the consciousness of the Imam’s living guidance.

عصری مسلمانوں کے لئے ، یہ آیت معاشرتی دباؤ کے باوجود ایمان کو برقرار رکھنے میں لچک کو متاثر کرتی ہے۔ یہ سکھاتا ہے کہ اخلاص ان عمل میں (*امل*) بیرونی توثیق سے زیادہ اہمیت رکھتا ہے ، اور مومنوں پر زور دیتا ہے کہ وہ دنیاوی قبولیت کو دور کرنے پر اللہ کی منظوری کو ترجیح دیں۔ عملی طور پر ، اس کا مطلب اخلاقی انتخاب میں ثابت قدمی ، انصاف کی وکالت کرنا ، یا قرآن سے کسی کا تعلق اور اماموں کی تعلیمات کو گہرا کرنا۔ عقیدے کے ساتھ اعمال کی صف بندی کرتے ہوئے - جیسا کہ نبی صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم نے کیا - مسلم * امل صالح * (نیک اعمال) کے قرآنی مثالی کو مجسم بناتے ہیں ، اس پر بھروسہ کرتے ہیں کہ الہی انصاف بالآخر غالب ہوگا۔

39.layer5:
In interpreting Quran 39:39, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on its core exhortation: a divine call to steadfastness in faith and action, coupled with eschatological accountability. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) alike contextualize the verse as Prophet Muhammad’s response to Quraysh’s resistance, urging them to adhere to their beliefs while he remains committed to divine truth, with ultimate judgment deferred to God. Ibn Kathir and Al-Tusi (Shia) both emphasize the verse’s moral imperative—actions rooted in conviction will face divine scrutiny—reflecting shared ethical principles across traditions.  

Divergences emerge in theological nuance. Shia commentaries like Al-Mizan (Tabatabai) and Tafsir al-Qummi link “your position” (مَكانَتِكُمْ) to one’s spiritual station contingent on accepting wilayah (divinely ordained leadership), arguing that true “work” aligns with the guidance of the Ahl al-Bayt. Al-Qummi explicitly ties the verse to the inevitability of recognizing the Imams’ authority in the hereafter. Sunni scholars, such as Al-Qurtubi and Al-Razi, interpret “position” more broadly as individual moral responsibility, independent of specific leadership structures. Al-Razi’s Mafatih al-Ghayb frames it as a universal call to act according to one’s sincere beliefs, whether aligned with truth or error.  

These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Shia tafsir integrates Imamah into Quranic hermeneutics, while Sunni exegesis prioritizes individual accountability under divine law. Practically, this influences Shia emphasis on adherence to Imamic guidance and Sunni focus on personal ijtihad within orthodox boundaries. Historically, such variations reflect early debates over religious authority post-Prophet Muhammad, crystallizing into distinct hermeneutical approaches. Both traditions, however, uphold the verse’s central theme: the inextricable link between earthly deeds and otherworldly reckoning.

39.summary: The scholarly view in Al-Mizan reveals that his exegesis of Quran 39:39, Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* elucidates that the divine command "work according to your position" addresses both the ontological reality of human capacity and the ethical imperative to align actions with one's spiritual state. In Surah Az-Zumar (39:39), Allah commands Prophet Muhammad (s) to address his people with a profound challenge rooted in personal accountability and divine truth. The verse’s core message—*"Work according to your position; I am working, and you will come to know"*—emphasizes the inevitability of divine justice and the consequences of human choices. The Arabic term *maqamatikum* (مَكَانَتِكُمْ), translated as "your position," refers to one’s spiritual, moral, and societal standing. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) states: *"Your deeds ascend only by the light of your recognition of us; actions are but branches, and Wilayah is their root"* (Al-Kafi). By aligning actions with faith—as the Prophet (s) did—Muslims embody the Quranic ideal of *amal saleh* (righteous deeds), trusting that divine justice will ultimately prevail.

40.layer1:
This verse from Surah Az-Zumar poses a grave rhetorical question, warning of two forms of divine punishment: one that brings humiliation (عَذَابٌ يُخْزِيهِ) and another that is unceasing (عَذَابٌ مُّقِيمٌ). Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, explains that the verse addresses those who persistently reject truth and choose arrogance over guidance. The “disgracing torment” refers to consequences that strip away worldly pretensions—exposing moral bankruptcy in this life or initial humiliation in the Hereafter—while the “enduring punishment” signifies the eternal Hellfire reserved for unrepentant oppressors and deniers of divine justice.  

Revealed in Mecca during intense persecution of early Muslims, this verse responded to Quraysh leaders who mocked Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and dismissed resurrection as a fantasy. Their material power and social status blinded them to accountability. The Arabic term *yukhzīhi* (يُخْزِيهِ) derives from *khizy*, meaning disgrace that dismantles false pride, while *muqīm* (مُّقِيمٌ) denotes permanence—a reality the Quran contrasts with the fleeting nature of worldly life.  

For contemporary Muslims, this verse is a timeless reminder to examine where we invest our arrogance or complacency. It calls us to humility before divine truth, whether in resisting harmful cultural norms, acknowledging errors, or prioritising spiritual integrity over social validation. Practically, it urges communities to collectively avoid the “disgrace” of moral decay—corruption, injustice, or neglect of the vulnerable—that can trigger societal collapse. Simultaneously, it instills consciousness of eternal consequences, motivating sincere tawbah (repentance) and alignment with the Qur’anic values upheld by the Ahlul Bayt (AS): justice, self-accountability, and detachment from transient illusions. By internalising these warnings, believers cultivate a balance of hope in Allah’s mercy and awe of His justice, anchoring actions in lasting spiritual purpose.
40.layer2:
In Surah Az-Zumar (39:40), the Qur'anic warning "To whom will come a torment disgracing him and on whom will descend an enduring punishment" is interpreted by classical Shia exegetes through theological and eschatological frameworks rooted in the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt. Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* distinguishes between the two forms of punishment: the "disgracing torment" (*‘adhāb yukhzīhi*) refers to worldly humiliation or intermediate chastisement in the grave (Barzakh), while the "enduring punishment" (*‘adhāb muqīm*) denotes eternal hellfire. This duality reflects the Shia understanding of divine justice operating across temporal and eternal planes, where transient worldly consequences foreshadow ultimate recompense.  

Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* emphasizes that the verse addresses those who persistently reject divine guidance despite clear proofs, linking their humiliation to spiritual blindness in this life. Both commentators stress that such punishment particularly befalls those who oppose the wilayah (divinely ordained authority) of the Ahlul Bayt, as their rejection constitutes a fundamental denial of truth. Tabatabai notes this aligns with the principle that divine wrath manifests against those who "exchange guidance for misguidance" (2:16), a theme recurrent in Shia theology regarding allegiance to the Imams.  

The verse’s theological depth connects to the Shia doctrine of *‘adl* (divine justice), wherein punishment is proportionate to one’s conscious defiance of truth. The "enduring punishment" underscores the irrevocability of divine judgment for unrepentant oppressors, resonating with narrations from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq describing hell as the inevitable abode for those who "know the truth yet fight it." Jurisprudentially, this verse reinforces the ethical imperative to align with the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings, as their guidance is deemed the sole path to avoid such fate. Thus, the verse serves as both a metaphysical warning and a call to uphold the ontological covenant of wilayah central to Shia soteriology.
40.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Az-Zumar (39:40) is often interpreted as a profound warning against moral complacency and systemic injustice. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, emphasizes that the "disgracing torment" and "enduring punishment" described here operate on both individual and societal levels. Modern scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this verse to the concept of *self-inflicted consequences*—arguing that societies embracing greed, environmental exploitation, or oppression effectively invite their own collapse, mirroring classical notions of divine justice (*‘adl*) manifesting through natural cause-effect relationships.  

Philosophically, the verse resonates with existential accountability in an age of climate crisis. Scholars like Sayyed Ammar Nakshawani note how ecological destruction—a "punishment" for human overreach—aligns with Quranic warnings about transgressing natural balance (*mīzān*). Socially, the verse critiques systemic inequalities; Dr. Liyakat Takim links enduring societal punishments—like poverty cycles or institutional racism—to collective failure in upholding Quranic equity.  

Interfaith parallels emerge in Buddhist teachings on *karma* and Christian concepts of societal sin, creating common ground for addressing global challenges. The verse’s multicultural relevance lies in its universal ethic: whether through AI ethics debates or refugee crises, humanity faces recurring tests of humility versus arrogance.  

Ultimately, this verse becomes a call for *tawba* (repentance) reimagined as systemic reform—a fusion of classical spirituality and modern activism. As contemporary Shia thinkers assert, the "enduring punishment" isn’t merely eschatological but manifests wherever humanity abandons its custodianship (*khilāfa*) of ethical and ecological duty.
40.layer4:
In the luminous teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them), this verse unveils a profound warning against spiritual blindness and rejection of divine guidance. Imam Ali (as) elucidates in *Nahj al-Balagha*: "The greatest torment is the heart’s hardening against the truth." The "disgracing torment" refers not only to the hereafter but to the inner degradation of souls who distance themselves from the light of Wilayah (divine guardianship). The Ahlul Bayt emphasize that true disgrace lies in rejecting the Imam appointed by Allah, for Imam Muhammad al-Baqir (as) states: "Whoever dies without recognizing the Imam of his time dies the death of ignorance" (*Bihar al-Anwar*).  

The "enduring punishment" signifies the eternal consequences of opposing the divine covenant of Imamah. Lady Fatimah (sa) declared in her historic sermon: "The unjust will face a painful punishment... for they exchanged Allah’s signs for denial." This verse thus warns that those who arrogantly dismiss the guidance of the purified Household invite both worldly humiliation and everlasting ruin.  

Spiritually, this verse calls believers to daily self-accountability. Imam Sadiq (as) taught: "The believer is a mirror to his brother; he must counsel him against self-delusion." Practical guidance lies in clinging to the rope of Ahlul Bayt – through studying their teachings, upholding justice, and seeking their intercession (tawassul). The enduring punishment is averted by anchoring the heart in love for the Fourteen Infallibles and embodying their ethics of humility, gratitude, and vigilance against spiritual heedlessness.  

Let every soul ask: Do my actions align with the standards of those whom Allah purified? As Imam Ali (as) advised: "Prepare answers for the questions of the Grave [about Wilayah], lest you be disgraced where disgrace is eternal.

40.layer5:
In interpreting Quran 39:40, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on its core eschatological message. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) agree the verse warns of inescapable divine punishment for those rejecting truth, with Al-Tabari emphasizing its application to Quraysh leaders who opposed the Prophet (Jami al-Bayan), while Al-Tabrisi (Majma al-Bayan) extends this to all who reject divine guidance through willful arrogance. Both traditions cite the "enduring punishment" as referencing Hell's eternity, as noted by Ibn Kathir (Tafsir al-Quran al-Azim) and Al-Tabarsi, reflecting shared eschatological principles.

Divergences emerge in contextual extensions. Shia commentaries like Al-Qummi’s Tafsir and Al-Tabtabai’s Al-Mizan incorporate narrations from the Ahl al-Bayt framing the verse as implicitly addressing rejection of legitimate leadership (wilayah). Al-Tabtabai interprets the "disgracing torment" as including spiritual deprivation from the Imams’ intercession, rooted in the Shia theological principle of Imamah as integral to divine guidance. Conversely, Sunni scholars like Al-Qurtubi (Al-Jami li-Ahkam) and Al-Razi (Mafatih al-Ghayb) focus on general moral failure without explicit leadership references, emphasizing individual accountability for rejecting prophethood and Quranic ethics.

These differences stem from distinct theological frameworks: Sunni exegesis prioritizes the Prophet’s Sunnah and communal consensus, while Shia tradition centers on the Ahl al-Bayt’s hermeneutic authority. Historically, Shia interpretations developed through narratives preserved by Imam Ali’s successors, whereas Sunni tafsir crystallized in scholarly circles valuing companion-based transmissions. Both approaches reinforce their respective communities’ spiritual priorities – Sunni emphasis on textual adherence versus Shia focus on allegiance to divinely appointed guides – without negating the verse’s universal moral imperative against arrogance and denial of truth.

40.summary: In analyzing this passage, Tabatabai explains that distinguishes between the two forms of punishment: the "disgracing torment" (*‘adhāb yukhzīhi*) refers to worldly humiliation or intermediate chastisement in the grave (Barzakh), while the "enduring punishment" (*‘adhāb muqīm*) denotes eternal hellfire. This verse from Surah Az-Zumar poses a grave rhetorical question, warning of two forms of divine punishment: one that brings humiliation (عَذَابٌ يُخْزِيهِ) and another that is unceasing (عَذَابٌ مُّقِيمٌ). Classical Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, explains that the verse addresses those who persistently reject truth and choose arrogance over guidance. The “disgracing torment” refers to consequences that strip away worldly pretensions—exposing moral bankruptcy in this life or initial humiliation in the Hereafter—while the “enduring punishment” signifies the eternal Hellfire reserved for unrepentant oppressors and deniers of divine justice. Imam Ali (as) elucidates in *Nahj al-Balagha*: "The greatest torment is the heart’s hardening against the truth. By internalising these warnings, believers cultivate a balance of hope in Allah’s mercy and awe of His justice, anchoring actions in lasting spiritual purpose.

41.layer1:
This verse from Surah Az-Zumar carries profound lessons about divine guidance and human responsibility. Allah begins by affirming the Quran’s purpose: *"Inna anzalna alayka al-kitaba lil-nasi bil-haqq"* (We sent down to you the Book for the people in truth). The term *al-haqq* (truth) underscores the Quran’s role as an unchanging, universal standard—a theme echoed in Shia tafsir by scholars like Allamah Tabatabai, who notes that the Quran’s truthfulness is inseparable from the guidance of the Ahlul Bayt, who embody its teachings. Historically, this verse reassured Prophet Muhammad (peace upon him) during periods of rejection by Quraysh leaders, clarifying that his duty was to convey the message, not compel belief.

The phrase *"faman ihtada fa li-nafsihi"* (whoever is guided, it is for their soul) highlights individual accountability—a cornerstone of Islamic theology. Guidance (*huda*) and misguidance (*dalal*) are framed as personal choices with eternal consequences. As Ayatollah Makarem Shirazi explains, Allah’s justice ensures everyone receives sufficient guidance through the Quran and divinely appointed leaders, but humans retain free will to accept or reject it. The closing line, *"wa ma anta alayhim biwakeel"* (you are not a manager over them), absolves the Prophet of responsibility for others’ choices, emphasizing that faith cannot be forced.

For modern Muslims, this verse invites reflection on personal spiritual agency. In an age of distractions, it reminds us to actively seek truth through the Quran and the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, rather than passively waiting for guidance. It also teaches tolerance: just as the Prophet wasn’t tasked with controlling others’ beliefs, we must avoid compulsion in faith matters while upholding our duty to share wisdom with compassion. Ultimately, it calls believers to internalize the Quran’s truths and take ownership of their spiritual journey, trusting that sincere seeking leads to divine light.
41.layer2:
In *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allamah Tabatabai elucidates this verse by emphasizing the ontological relationship between divine guidance and human accountability. He notes that the Qur’an’s revelation is described as being “in truth” (*bil-haqq*), signifying its role as an absolute, objective criterion for distinguishing between guidance and misguidance. The verse’s declaration that the Prophet (s) is “not a manager over them” underscores the theological principle of human free will (*ikhtiyar*) within Shia thought: while the Book provides universal guidance, individuals bear responsibility for their spiritual trajectory. Tabatabai links this to the Shia doctrine of *lutf* (divine grace), wherein Allah facilitates guidance through revelation and the Ahl al-Bayt (as), yet without negating human agency.

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, highlights the verse’s ethical dimension, observing that guidance accrues solely to the benefit of the soul (*li-nafsihi*), while misguidance harms only the self. This duality reflects the Shia understanding of *ma’ad* (eschatology), wherein each soul is resurrected according to its acquired disposition. The phrase “you are not a manager over them” is interpreted as a reminder of the Prophet’s (s) role as a warner (*nadhir*) rather than a coercive authority, a theme consistent with Qur’anic narratives of prophetic missions. 

Classical commentaries connect this verse to the broader Shia principle of *walayah*, asserting that while the Qur’an is the foundational guide, its true interpretation resides with the Imams (as) from the Prophet’s progeny. As Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as) states in a related tradition, “The Book is the silent guide; we are its speaking interpreters.” Thus, the verse implicitly affirms the necessity of both the textual revelation and the living guidance of the Ahl al-Bayt (as) for comprehensive spiritual direction. The absence of prophetic compulsion (*jabr*) here complements Shia jurisprudential frameworks that prioritize informed moral choice as the basis for divine accountability.
41.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Az-Zumar 41 is often framed as a profound affirmation of human agency within divine guidance. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemouneh*, emphasizes that the verse establishes the Quran as an eternal "manual for truth" while underscoring individual accountability—a concept resonant with modern philosophical debates about free will versus determinism. Scholars like Sayyid Kamal al-Haydari connect this to the Qur’anic principle of *la ikraha fi’d-din* (no compulsion in religion), arguing that the verse rejects coercive proselytization, aligning with contemporary human rights frameworks on religious freedom.

Modern thinkers, such as Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, contextualize this verse within pluralistic societies, noting that while the Quran offers universal truths, it acknowledges diverse spiritual trajectories—a perspective vital for interfaith dialogue in multicultural settings. Philosophically, the verse’s focus on self-directed guidance intersects with psychological theories of intrinsic motivation, suggesting that authentic faith arises from personal engagement rather than external imposition.

Socially, the verse speaks to current challenges like ideological polarization and misinformation. As Grand Ayatollah Hussein Ismail al-Sadr observes, the Quran’s role as a "truth compass" counters today’s "post-truth" culture, urging communities to prioritize ethical literacy over dogmatic echo chambers. Scientifically, neuroscientific insights into decision-making align with the verse’s emphasis on conscious choice: just as neural pathways strengthen through repeated actions, spiritual guidance requires active, sustained effort.

Ultimately, this verse bridges divine invitation and human responsibility—a dynamic mirrored in global efforts to balance collective welfare with individual autonomy. It reminds us that while the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings illuminate the path, each soul must walk it freely, making the pursuit of truth both a personal journey and a shared civilizational imperative.
41.layer4:
In this profound verse, Allah reminds humanity that the Quran was revealed through the Final Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him and his family) as the ultimate criterion of truth, yet guidance remains a matter of conscious choice illuminated by the spiritual guardianship of the Ahlul Bayt. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught in *Nahj al-Balagha*: "The Quran is a guide that speaks; its speech does not die. It is a house whose pillars do not fall." The Book's eternal light manifests through the living guidance of the Imams, for as Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explained: "We are the 'managers' [wakil] mentioned in the Quran when Allah says 'You are not a manager over them' – meaning the true custodianship lies with the Imams of Truth."

The verse's declaration that guidance benefits the soul while misguidance self-destructs reflects the Shia understanding of *wilayah* as the axis of salvation. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) stated: "Allah made obedience to us the order for harmony and our leadership a safeguard from division." To "be guided" in this context means recognizing the divine light vested in the Prophet's purified progeny. Imam al-Baqir (peace be upon him) taught that "Whoever dies without knowing the Imam of his time dies the death of ignorance," emphasizing that Quranic guidance remains incomplete without allegiance to the living Imam.

Practically, this verse calls believers to daily renew their covenant with the Ahlul Bayt through sincere supplication, ethical refinement, and seeking sacred knowledge. As Imam Zayn al-Abidin (peace be upon him) prayed in *Sahifa Sajjadiyya*: "Make us among those who hold fast to Your cord, who follow the footsteps of Your Prophet...and whom You have chosen for the service of Your friends." True guidance blossoms when we make our hearts receptacles for the Quran's light as interpreted by those whom the Quran itself calls the *Thaqalayn* (Two Weighty Things)

سور Surah ایز زومار کی یہ آیت الہی رہنمائی اور انسانی ذمہ داری کے بارے میں گہرے سبق رکھتی ہے۔ اللہ کا آغاز قرآن کے مقصد کی تصدیق کرتے ہوئے ہوتا ہے: * "اننا انزالنا الیاکا الکیٹابا لِل ناسی بل حق" * (ہم نے حقیقت میں لوگوں کے لئے آپ کو کتاب بھیجی ہے)۔ اصطلاح * الحق * (سچ) قرآن مجید کے ایک غیر متزلزل ، آفاقی معیار کی حیثیت سے اس کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے۔ یہ ایک موضوع الامہ تبتابائی جیسے اسکالرز کے ذریعہ شیعہ طافسر میں گونجتا ہے ، جو نوٹ کرتے ہیں کہ قرآن کی سچائی کو اہل بیت کی رہنمائی سے الگ نہیں ہے۔ تاریخی طور پر ، اس آیت نے قریش کے رہنماؤں کے مسترد ہونے کے ادوار کے دوران نبی محمد (ان پر امن) کو یقین دلایا ، اور یہ واضح کیا کہ اس کا فرض یہ ہے کہ وہ اس پیغام کو مجبور کرے ، نہ کہ یقین پر مجبور کریں۔

یہ جملہ * "فامن ایہٹاڈا ایف اے لی نافسیہی" * (جو بھی رہنمائی کرتا ہے ، یہ ان کی روح کے لئے ہے) انفرادی احتساب کو اجاگر کرتا ہے-اسلامی الہیات کا ایک سنگ بنیاد۔ رہنمائی (*ہوڈا*) اور غلط فہمی (*دلال*) کو ابدی نتائج کے ساتھ ذاتی انتخاب کے طور پر تیار کیا گیا ہے۔ جیسا کہ آیت اللہ مکارم شیرازی نے وضاحت کی ہے ، اللہ کا انصاف اس بات کو یقینی بناتا ہے کہ ہر شخص قرآن اور خدائی مقرر کردہ رہنماؤں کے ذریعہ کافی رہنمائی حاصل کرے ، لیکن انسان اسے قبول کرنے یا اسے مسترد کرنے کی آزادانہ خواہش برقرار رکھتے ہیں۔ اختتامی لکیر ، * "وا ما اینٹا الہیم بائوکیل" * (آپ ان پر مینیجر نہیں ہیں) ، دوسروں کے انتخاب کی ذمہ داری کے نبی کو ختم کردیتے ہیں ، اور اس بات پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ ایمان کو مجبور نہیں کیا جاسکتا۔

جدید مسلمانوں کے لئے ، یہ آیت ذاتی روحانی ایجنسی پر عکاسی کی دعوت دیتی ہے۔ خلفشار کے دور میں ، یہ ہمیں یاد دلاتا ہے کہ وہ قرآن مجید اور اہل بیت کی تعلیمات کے ذریعے فعال طور پر سچائی تلاش کریں ، بجائے اس کے کہ وہ رہنمائی کا غیر فعال انتظار کریں۔ یہ رواداری بھی سکھاتا ہے: جس طرح نبی. کو دوسروں کے عقائد کو کنٹرول کرنے کا کام سونپا نہیں گیا تھا ، اسی طرح ہمیں ہمدردی کے ساتھ حکمت بانٹنے کے لئے اپنے فرض کو برقرار رکھنے کے دوران ایمان کے معاملات میں مجبوری سے بچنا چاہئے۔ آخر کار ، یہ مومنوں کو قرآن کی سچائیوں کو اندرونی بنانے اور ان کے روحانی سفر کی ملکیت لینے کا مطالبہ کرتا ہے ، اس پر بھروسہ کرتے ہیں کہ مخلصانہ تلاش خدائی روشنی کی طرف جاتا ہے۔

تبریسی ،*مجس البیان*میں ، آیت کی اخلاقی جہت کو اجاگر کرتی ہے ، یہ مشاہدہ کرتی ہے کہ رہنمائی مکمل طور پر روح (*لی نافسی*) کے مفاد کے لئے جمع ہوتی ہے ، جبکہ غلط فہمی صرف خود کو نقصان پہنچاتی ہے۔ یہ دوغلا پن * ماڈ * (اسکیٹولوجی) کی شیعہ کی تفہیم کی عکاسی کرتا ہے ، جس میں ہر روح کو اس کے حصول کے مطابق زندہ کیا جاتا ہے۔ "آپ ان پر مینیجر نہیں ہیں" کے فقرے کی ترجمانی ایک زبردستی اتھارٹی کے بجائے وارنر (*نڈھیر*) کی حیثیت سے نبی کے کردار کی یاد دہانی کے طور پر کی گئی ہے ، جو پیشن گوئی مشنوں کے قرآنی بیانیہ کے مطابق ہے۔ 

کلاسیکی تبصرے اس آیت کو *والیاہ *کے وسیع تر شیعہ اصول سے مربوط کرتے ہیں ، اور یہ کہتے ہوئے کہ قرآن مجید بنیادی رہنما ہے ، لیکن اس کی اصل تشریح نبی کی اولاد سے امام (ع) کے ساتھ ہے۔ جیسا کہ امام جعفر السادق (ع) ایک متعلقہ روایت میں بیان کرتے ہیں ، "کتاب خاموش رہنما ہے۔ ہم اس کے بولنے والے ترجمان ہیں۔" اس طرح ، آیت جامع روحانی سمت کے لئے عبوری طور پر متنی وحی اور اے ایچ ایل ال بیت (ع) کی زندہ رہنمائی دونوں کی ضرورت کی تصدیق کرتی ہے۔ پیشن گوئی کی مجبوری (*جبر*) کی عدم موجودگی شیعہ فقہی فریم ورک کو پورا کرتی ہے جو اخلاقی انتخاب کو الہی احتساب کی بنیاد کے طور پر ترجیح دیتے ہیں۔

اس گہری آیت میں ، اللہ انسانیت کو یاد دلاتا ہے کہ قرآن مجید کو حتمی نبی محمد (اس پر اور اس کے اہل خانہ پر امن) کے ذریعہ انکشاف کیا گیا ہے کیونکہ یہ حقیقت کے حتمی معیار کے طور پر ہے ، پھر بھی رہنمائی اہل بیت کی روحانی سرپرستی سے روشن شعوری انتخاب کا معاملہ ہے۔ امام علی (اس پر سلامتی) *ناہج البالاگھا *میں پڑھایا گیا: "قرآن ایک رہنما ہے جو بولتا ہے۔ اس کی تقریر نہیں مرتی۔ یہ وہ گھر ہے جس کے ستون نہیں گرتے ہیں۔" کتاب کی ابدی روشنی اماموں کی زندہ رہنمائی کے ذریعہ ظاہر ہوتی ہے ، کیوں کہ جیسا کہ امام جعفر السادق (ان پر امن ہے) نے وضاحت کی: "ہم قرآن مجید میں ذکر کردہ 'مینیجرز' [واکیل] ہیں جب اللہ کہتے ہیں کہ 'آپ ان پر مینیجر نہیں ہیں'۔

عملی طور پر ، یہ آیت مومنوں کو مخلصانہ التجا ، اخلاقی تطہیر ، اور مقدس علم کے حصول کے ذریعہ اہل بیت کے ساتھ روزانہ اپنے عہد کی تجدید کرنے کا مطالبہ کرتی ہے۔ جیسا کہ امام زین العبدین (اس پر امن ہے) نے *ساہفا سججدیہ *میں دعا کی تھی: "ہمیں ان لوگوں میں شامل کریں جو آپ کی ہڈی کو تیز رفتار رکھتے ہیں ، جو آپ کے نبی کے نقش قدم پر چلتے ہیں ... اور جن کو آپ نے اپنے دوستوں کی خدمت کے لئے منتخب کیا ہے۔" جب ہم اپنے دلوں کو قرآن کی روشنی کے ل rec رسیپٹیکل بناتے ہیں تو حقیقی رہنمائی پھول جاتی ہے جس کی ترجمانی ان لوگوں کی ہے جن کو قرآن خود * تھاقالین * (دو وزن دار چیزیں) کہتے ہیں۔
41.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Az-Zumar 39:41, both Shia and Sunni scholars emphasize the Quran’s universal truth and human moral accountability. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tusi (Shia) concur that the verse affirms divine guidance through revelation while underscoring human free will: individuals bear responsibility for their choices, as noted in Al-Mizan (Tabatabai) and Ibn Kathir’s tafsir. Both traditions agree the Prophet’s role is to convey the message, not to compel belief, aligning with Al-Qurtubi’s emphasis on the Prophet’s limited agency and Al-Tabrisi’s (Shia) assertion that guidance depends on personal receptivity.

Divergences emerge in theological implications. Sunni exegetes like Al-Razi frame “guidance” as adherence to Quranic principles and the Sunnah, stressing communal interpretation (ijma) and scholarly consensus. In contrast, Shia commentaries such as Tafsir al-Qummi link true guidance to allegiance to the Ahl al-Bayt, viewing the Imams as essential interpreters safeguarding Quranic truth—a perspective rooted in the historical context of early Shia emphasis on divinely appointed leadership after the Prophet. This theological distinction influences religious practice, with Shia communities prioritizing the Imams’ teachings in jurisprudence and spirituality, while Sunni traditions emphasize the Sahaba’s legacy and scholarly institutions.

Historically, these differences stem from distinct epistemological frameworks: Sunni thought developed alongside evolving legal schools, whereas Shia hermeneutics centered on the Imams’ infallible authority. Both traditions, however, maintain the verse’s core message of individual accountability, reflecting shared ethical foundations despite divergent theological lenses.
